positive.review: It’s nice that the game lets you explore different scenarios without feeling judged. Definitely boosted my mood more than once.

The game has a ton of bugs in it. From the friend's list, to the profile page, to players constantly having to refresh their avatars during game play. In fact most players call it "BugCraft" and not LoveCraft. 

I would encourage the game design team to get busy with fixes / updates!

Personally for me this game is way more than what it's advertised for. it's about the community, meeting interesting people from all around the world, making friends, expressing yourself through your character and style, it's about creativity and gaining skills in something you never thought you had ability for until you tried. it's about fully immersing yourself in this made up world and forgetting all the stress and hustle irl. I recommend it purely for all the things I have mentioned. You can get way more than you imagine, give it a try and you will understand what I am talking about. :)
I play it not just for pleasure but for peace - it really melts away stress and tension. The atmosphere is calming, the visuals gorgeous, and the emotions sincere.

The “I Didn’t Expect That” Review

After more than 10 hours in LoveCraft, I’ve learned one thing:
This game is basically The Sims if everyone skipped therapy and went straight to the party.

Pros

Super chill — you can vibe, dance, flirt, or just stand there like an NPC questioning your life choices.
Customization lets you cook up anything from “cute” to “I regret nothing.”
Social moments can be absolute chaos in the best way.
Free-to-play, so your wallet takes 0 emotional damage.

Cons

It’s… very adult. Like “Steam please don’t look at my Recently Played” adult.
Actual gameplay? Yeah, not really. It’s 80% socializing, 20% you trying to figure out what you’re doing.
If the server’s empty, it feels like you’re exploring a nightclub at 5 AM.
No real goals — just vibes and questionable decisions.

Final Take

Fun to hop in, mess around, maybe flirt badly, then log off questioning your life path.
3/5 — chaotic good, but not exactly deep.

LoveCraft, developed and published by WEALTHBIRD, presents itself as a socially driven virtual world rather than a traditional game with objectives, levels, or scripted progression. Its foundation lies in player expression, interpersonal interaction, and the creation of a shared digital space where community behavior defines the experience more than any developer-authored story. From the moment players enter the world, it’s clear that LoveCraft is built for those who want to socialize, explore, flirt, customize their avatars, and participate in loosely structured gatherings rather than chase achievements or complete quests. The tone is unapologetically adult, leaning into seductive themes, nightlife environments, and provocative aesthetics, which immediately sets its identity apart from more generalized social simulators.

LoveCraft’s world design reflects its emphasis on freedom and personal style. Character customization is extensive, giving players the chance to sculpt avatars that reflect fantasy identities rather than strict realism. Clothing, poses, accessories, and expressive animations help players communicate without needing dense dialogue systems. Social hubs—a mix of lounges, party venues, scenic locations, or hidden corners—serve as stages for emergent storytelling, spontaneous role-play, or casual conversation. The environments may not be expansive open worlds, but they’re crafted with enough mood and personality to encourage exploration and gathering. Audio, lighting, and visual effects contribute to a club-like atmosphere, reinforcing the game’s sensual, nightlife-driven identity.

Because gameplay revolves around social expression rather than mechanics, the community becomes the primary source of engagement. Players may enter looking for conversation, companionship, role-play scenarios, or simply to observe the interactions around them. The experience can be satisfying if the player arrives with curiosity and initiative—those who approach others, experiment with customization, and attend social events will likely get more out of the game. However, this also means LoveCraft’s value fluctuates based on server activity, time of day, and the willingness of others to interact. The game fosters an environment where the players shape their own narratives, which can be liberating for some and directionless for others.

Its free-to-play model lowers the entry barrier, allowing anyone to step into the world without financial commitment. But like many social simulators, monetization centers on cosmetic enhancements and avatar upgrades, meaning the most eye-catching personalizations tend to require real-world payment. This doesn’t break the experience, but it does create a visual distinction between casual users and those more financially invested. For players motivated by aesthetic expression or digital identity building, the temptation to spend can be strong. Meanwhile, those satisfied with baseline customization will still have access to the core social experience, though perhaps with fewer expressive tools.

The adult content component is both the game’s defining feature and its most divisive quality. LoveCraft embraces erotic themes openly, and its environments, interactions, and customization options reflect that creative direction. For adults seeking a space where sensual fantasy and social interaction coexist comfortably, this may feel refreshing and honest. However, players expecting broader gameplay systems, competitive modes, narrative progression, or general-audience community activities may feel out of place. The game is built very clearly for a mature audience, and it does not apologize for its niche.

Despite its strengths, LoveCraft also carries the limitations common to socially driven virtual spaces. Without structured objectives or long-term progression, the experience depends heavily on the player’s engagement style and the active community at any given moment. Some players may crave clearer goals or minigames that supplement social interaction, while others may be turned off by the adult-centered tone. Technical polish, environmental variety, and community moderation will all influence how welcoming or sustainable the world feels over time. The game can be a lively digital playground, but like any social platform, its energy fluctuates.

Ultimately, LoveCraft thrives on the freedom it grants its audience. It succeeds as a space for mature social fantasy—an online gathering spot built around style, identity, sensuality, and human curiosity. It doesn’t try to compete with expansive RPGs or action-heavy multiplayer titles, nor does it attempt to dilute its personality for mass appeal. Instead, it offers a virtual world where personal expression and interpersonal dynamics are the gameplay. For players who enjoy avatar-driven social interaction, improvisational role-play, or simply meeting new people in a stylish adult setting, LoveCraft can be engaging and memorable. For those seeking structure, challenge, or narrative depth, it may feel hollow. Its value ultimately lies in what the player brings to it—and how willing they are to help shape the world themselves.

Didn’t expect to enjoy this game so much. The character interactions feel super natural, and it actually helped me to unwind.

I started playing this game not long ago, and honestly, it surprised me in the best way. The community is very friendly, and I’ve met some amazing people here — especially my clan, F O X E S, who made the whole experience even more special. The atmosphere of the game is wonderful warm, social, and full of creativity. There’s always something to do: exploring, customizing your character, or just hanging out and chatting with others.
The only thing I’d mention is that the optimization could be better at times, but the charm and atmosphere of the game easily make up for it. You just want to stay longer and keep discovering more about this world.
Totally worth trying if you enjoy games that make you feel connected and inspired.

Honestly, it’s a real love–hate relationship with this game. Lovecraft or Bugcraft… I’m not even sure anymore. There are so many annoying issues. I’m running 32GB game at times uses 80% of my memory (non event on ultra), how is that even possible? And the bugs… it’s insane how many there are. The number of crashes is through the roof. I’ve stopped counting; it’s a daily struggle.

What frustrates me most is that they keep pumping out new content all the time. As a BDSM fan, I was thrilled to see the cross and other BDSM assets added to the store. Unfortunately, I can’t use them with my partner because they only work for heterosexual setups, same with cars and other features. It’s honestly demotivating. So i legit had to make another character to test or use it.. but its just not the same.. 

But despite all that, I’m still playing daily. It’s the community, the people, the kindness, the support, that keeps you hooked. I would honestly prefer 1 assets a month that work for everyone instead of 10–20 new things that half the playerbase can’t or won’t use.

So yes… it’s definitely a love/hate relationship.

I have to say, I've been completely addicted to this game since I started a few weeks ago. I've had a few bad experience with some people, but I've also had some amazing ones, too. That might be the most interesting aspect of the game to me... it's variance. Of course there's sex, yes, and that's fun, but the newness fades after a while and what you're left with are all the friends and connections you've made, and it sort of just becomes a place to hang and chill with friends with occasional sex when you feel like it. But what's amazed me the most is seeing the broad range of potential types of interactions and moments you could have on any given day. There's so much variance once you get past the surface level. You never really know what might happen during the course of a day if you remain open to the possibilities, and it seems like I'm always finding new wrinkles and new ways to play that maybe I hadn't thought of before. It allows you to be creative and choose you're own way to play, and to me, that's the game's greatest strength. It's fascinating how, quite often, it mirrors real life in several ways. Overall, it's been a great time so far. Full disclosure, the game can be pretty buggy at times, but I still keep coming back because it's just so different from anything else I've ever played. Definitely recommended.

Lovecraft is a surprisingly fun and social experience that blends creativity, community, and a touch of eerie charm. It’s a great place to meet new people — the community feels active and welcoming, and conversations tend to flow naturally as you build, explore, and trade.

The in-game currency system is well-balanced, which is refreshing compared to many online games where microtransactions dominate. Earning and spending feels fair, and you can progress without feeling pressured to spend real money.

There are a few minor bugs here and there, but most are easily fixed with a quick refresh, so they don’t take away from the overall experience. The shop features themed items that fit perfectly with the game’s mysterious, Lovecraft-inspired atmosphere — collecting and customizing them is a highlight.

Building mechanics are another strong point. It’s fun and surprisingly deep, letting you express your creativity while still feeling accessible to newcomers.

Overall, Lovecraft is a well-designed social game that delivers a good mix of interaction, creativity, and style. If you enjoy making friends and crafting your own locations, this game is definitely worth checking out.

negative.review:
So… I tried playing LoveCraft, and honestly, this game is lowkey wild but not in a good way. I’m running 16GB RAM, which is literally standard for pretty much every modern game, and this thing STILL managed to choke my system.

The RAM usage just keeps climbing nonstop like it’s trying to speedrun self-destruction. It doesn’t cap, it doesn’t stabilize, it just yoinks all available memory until my Arch Linux steps in like “nah bro, we’re not dying today” and force-kills both the game and Steam as a safety measure.
Even after adding an extra [b]8GB swapfile[/b], which should at least give it some breathing room, the game still crashes. That’s honestly crazy for a release in this era.

Performance aside, the overall quality feels super rough. Janky, unoptimized, and feels like it wasn’t tested properly. I’ve played tons of indie titles, and this is one of the rare ones where the system stability suffers more than the gameplay experience.

If the devs don’t fix this memory leak soon, it’s basically unplayable.
Would not recommend in its current state (｡•́︿•̀｡)

first of all, my expectations were already bottomed out below the floor for this game. most games like this are built solely on the idea of gooning and thats it.

imagine my surprise when i get on for the first time and i see a bunch of people i've never met before hanging out in "clans" together and partying hard and being social

now im sure you are asking yourself, "then why the negative review?"

well i'll tell you why: its not the players, or the community driven events, or the gooning

the Devs of this MMO are some of the most erratically out of touch people i've ever had the displeasure of dealing with

first of all, the game master server is located somewhere in Russia, that much is evident by the sheer number of untranslated UI elements. they haven't been fixed yet numerous players have complained about it

wanna know what else hasn't been fixed

-the stupidly long loading times
-the random server time-outs
-the server being unoptimized to the point where playing with graphics settings set to anything higher than the lowest settings make it run at (and i shit you not) 5 fps MAX
-spawning into event spaces still placing your character underneath the world

the list goes on, and yet the devs still push out new paid animations and items to goon with
really makes me wonder if the devs actually give a care about the game or the communities within it or if its solely to make a quick buck from down bad gooner elites who cant live without gooning 24/7

time tells all i guess

First launch: I can see the vision... but the game ran in fits and starts, areas with lots of avatars ran horrifically slowly while areas without avatars ran decently well.    

Second launch: Spent 10 minutes waiting for this game to load - after consuming 40+% of my 8 core/16 thread 10th Gen CPU, nearly 9 GB of RAM and 70+% of my RTX 2060... it never completed loading but turned my system into a wind tunnel.  Poor.

Overall impression: Not ready for prime time.

Utter slop with an insane pricing for in game currency, it barely runs, the models are atrocious and the animations are worse than that, but it's worth looking at if you want a laugh. Absolutely hilarious

If you enjoy folks standing around and probably doing nothing but private chatting with each other, then this is for you.  Otherwise, don't expect much aside from a lot of dancing emotes and time wasting.  The servers are slow to load and once you get in there is some def lag at times. More than once I got got caught running in one place cause the game/server couldn't keep up with everything going on.  Controls are....janky....hold both shift keys to really run...and at times there is a delay in them as well.  Also, the music seems to be coming from a youtube channel or such cause you get weird commercials in the middle of the game for stuff that isn't involved in the game at all - ads fro optimum and dairy queen. Has potential but needs a lot of work.

[ENG]
This game is not only riddled with a thousand bugs that could turn your gaming PC into an exploding microwave, but it's also filled with incompetent and deeply homophobic developers and staff.

They never update animations for the gay player community, yet they update for other groups (exclusively lesbians and heterosexuals) almost weekly.

Worse still, the game's owner/administrator (Mi**y) is very unprofessional and rude. Whenever anyone questions the games lack of gay animation updates and the subtle implicit gay hatred, he immediately closes multiple players' support tickets without any explanation or answers. 

So if you're a gay dude looking for fun in a kinky virtual world, don't waste your time and go find a better game. We're clearly not welcome here.

[CN]
这款游戏不仅布满了可能让你的游戏电脑变成爆炸微波炉的千百个漏洞，更充斥着无能且充满深层恐同倾向的开发者和工作人员。

他们从未为同性恋玩家群体更新动画效果，却几乎每周为其他群体（仅限女同性恋者和异性恋者）进行更新。

更糟的是，游戏所有者/管理员（Mi**y）极其不专业且态度粗鲁。每当有人质疑游戏缺乏同性恋动画更新及隐含的反同倾向时，他便立即关闭多名玩家的支持工单，拒绝任何解释或答复。

所以如果你是想在变态虚拟世界寻欢作乐的同志，别浪费时间了，赶紧去找更好的游戏吧。我们显然在这里不受欢迎。

first of all, my expectations were already bottomed out below the floor for this game. most games like this are built solely on the idea of gooning and thats it.

imagine my surprise when i get on for the first time and i see a bunch of people i've never met before hanging out in "clans" together and partying hard and being social

now im sure you are asking yourself, "then why the negative review?"

well i'll tell you why: its not the players, or the community driven events, or the gooning

the Devs of this MMO are some of the most erratically out of touch people i've ever had the displeasure of dealing with

first of all, the game master server is located somewhere in Russia, that much is evident by the sheer number of untranslated UI elements. they haven't been fixed yet numerous players have complained about it

wanna know what else hasn't been fixed

-the stupidly long loading times
-the random server time-outs
-the server being unoptimized to the point where playing with graphics settings set to anything higher than the lowest settings make it run at (and i shit you not) 5 fps MAX
-spawning into event spaces still placing your character underneath the world

the list goes on, and yet the devs still push out new paid animations and items to goon with
really makes me wonder if the devs actually give a care about the game or the communities within it or if its solely to make a quick buck from down bad gooner elites who cant live without gooning 24/7

time tells all i guess

First launch: I can see the vision... but the game ran in fits and starts, areas with lots of avatars ran horrifically slowly while areas without avatars ran decently well.    

Second launch: Spent 10 minutes waiting for this game to load - after consuming 40+% of my 8 core/16 thread 10th Gen CPU, nearly 9 GB of RAM and 70+% of my RTX 2060... it never completed loading but turned my system into a wind tunnel.  Poor.

Overall impression: Not ready for prime time.

i downloaded this as a joke to play with a friend and mess around. little did i know this game would max out my 32 gigabytes of ram on my system. this game is either horridly unoptimized or it is doing something malicious on your pc while running it

⭐☆☆☆☆

Playtime: 60 minutes

30 minutes: Trying to fix the lag

10 minutes: Realizing there’s no fixing the lag

20 minutes: Watching a guy ride a horse with a fire extinguisher inside an apartment while people were having bathtub org!es and strangers spammed emojis

PC Specs (a.k.a. Sacrificial Offering to LoveCraft):

Ryzen 5600x

RTX 3070

32 GB RAM (12 GB held hostage by this game)

2TB NVMe SSD

FPS achieved: 15 (on a good day)

So here’s the deal: LoveCraft is free. But nothing in this “game” actually feels free, except regret.

Let’s talk performance.
My rig can run Cyberpunk 2077 at max settings like it’s butter on a hot pan. LoveCraft? Barely crawls above 15 FPS, even on low settings, while rendering what looks like 2005-era Second Life knockoff graphics. My character was basically a Picasso painting in 3D. I opened Task Manager and the game was chewing 12GB of RAM just idling in the menu. For reference, Elden Ring doesn’t even do that.

Now let’s talk monetization.
This is where the comedy gold really begins. Behold:

Premium Plan ($45):

5% discount in the store (wow, thanks for the generosity 🙄)

Create three avatars (because two would be too mainstream)

“High-end real estate” (translation: a digital shoebox apartment)

Colored nickname and a little icon so everyone knows you paid real money for fake clout.

VIP Plan ($350):

All sex animations are FREE. Yes, apparently animations cost money otherwise.

20% store discount (still overpriced as hell)

Transfer golden coins, extra avatars, blah blah…

The true prize: a yellow name and a little “VIP” badge so everyone knows you spent $350 to roleplay as a h0rny landlord in low-res graphics.

I’m sorry, but who in their right mind spends three hundred and fifty dollars for this? For that price, you could buy a Steam Deck and play literally anything else.

And don’t get me started on the in-game shop:

Clothes: a pair of underwear costs more gold than an actual Calvin Klein set. Not exaggerating.

Pets: there is a giant soft c0ck with eyes and a mouth you can buy for $20. That’s not even funny, it’s just terrifying.

Mounts: You can buy mountains to ride. Yes. You pay to sit on geological formations.

The only “realistic” part of this game is that housing is stupid expensive. You want a house? That’s $50 USD. And it looks like a box from The Sims 1.

My actual experience in-game:
I log in, the game immediately stutters like a dying fish. After trying to fix lag for half an hour, I gave up. Then I wandered into an apartment where a dude was riding a horse with a fire extinguisher, while another group was roleplaying a bathtub 0rgy with a live emoji audience. At that moment, I realized: this isn’t a game. This is performance art made entirely out of bad decisions.

Comparison time:

VRChat: 7,538.4 hours (yes, mostly ERP, but at least it’s fun and customizable). I can build worlds, upload avatars, dance with friends, and ERP in anime catgirl form, all for free.

LoveCraft: 60 minutes, and I feel like I need therapy.

Even S3x with H!tler is more honest than this trash. At least that game doesn’t pretend to be anything more than what it is.

Final Verdict:
LoveCraft is “free,” but the real price is your dignity.

💀 0/10. Would rather spend $350 on actual Calvin Klein underwear than fake pixels.
Maybe I'm missing something, but it seems like this is just an Adult version of various other social media gimmicks.  I don't need or want that.

Well, despite spending a lot of time here, the game disappoints me. The game mechanics are archaic, the game can freeze during "encounters", and returning is often difficult due to lenghty data loading times. Many nice initial relationships fall apart before they even begin. It's a nightmare....but if someone, usually a lot of kids - most of who are here - want quick, shotr, and meaningless encounters, then this game is for them. Not for friendship, you won't find it here. It's for, i guess, the foolish satisfaction of emotionally immature children.

Plenty of Glitches to go around. nothing to do really. honestly reminds me of a cheap knock off of Second Life. But with less things to do. I guess they are trying but it's too little right now. Not to mention there are more kids here then adults. No one knows how to communicate and defaults to asking for sex from anyone. Just a boring game I tried to give it sometime to grow on me. But really hasn't, only fun thing is all the outfits. But just...not worth it over all.

So… I tried playing LoveCraft, and honestly, this game is lowkey wild but not in a good way. I’m running 16GB RAM, which is literally standard for pretty much every modern game, and this thing STILL managed to choke my system.

The RAM usage just keeps climbing nonstop like it’s trying to speedrun self-destruction. It doesn’t cap, it doesn’t stabilize, it just yoinks all available memory until my Arch Linux steps in like “nah bro, we’re not dying today” and force-kills both the game and Steam as a safety measure.
Even after adding an extra [b]8GB swapfile[/b], which should at least give it some breathing room, the game still crashes. That’s honestly crazy for a release in this era.

Performance aside, the overall quality feels super rough. Janky, unoptimized, and feels like it wasn’t tested properly. I’ve played tons of indie titles, and this is one of the rare ones where the system stability suffers more than the gameplay experience.

If the devs don’t fix this memory leak soon, it’s basically unplayable.
Would not recommend in its current state (｡•́︿•̀｡)

So… I tried playing LoveCraft, and honestly, this game is lowkey wild but not in a good way. I’m running 16GB RAM, which is literally standard for pretty much every modern game, and this thing STILL managed to choke my system.

The RAM usage just keeps climbing nonstop like it’s trying to speedrun self-destruction. It doesn’t cap, it doesn’t stabilize, it just yoinks all available memory until my Arch Linux steps in like “nah bro, we’re not dying today” and force-kills both the game and Steam as a safety measure.
Even after adding an extra [b]8GB swapfile[/b], which should at least give it some breathing room, the game still crashes. That’s honestly crazy for a release in this era.

Performance aside, the overall quality feels super rough. Janky, unoptimized, and feels like it wasn’t tested properly. I’ve played tons of indie titles, and this is one of the rare ones where the system stability suffers more than the gameplay experience.

If the devs don’t fix this memory leak soon, it’s basically unplayable.
Would not recommend in its current state (｡•́︿•̀｡)

If you enjoy folks standing around and probably doing nothing but private chatting with each other, then this is for you.  Otherwise, don't expect much aside from a lot of dancing emotes and time wasting.  The servers are slow to load and once you get in there is some def lag at times. More than once I got got caught running in one place cause the game/server couldn't keep up with everything going on.  Controls are....janky....hold both shift keys to really run...and at times there is a delay in them as well.  Also, the music seems to be coming from a youtube channel or such cause you get weird commercials in the middle of the game for stuff that isn't involved in the game at all - ads fro optimum and dairy queen. Has potential but needs a lot of work.

They never update animations for the gay player community, yet they update for other groups (exclusively lesbians and heterosexuals) almost weekly.

Worse still, the game's owner/administrator (Mi**y) is very unprofessional and rude. Whenever anyone questions the games lack of gay animation updates and the subtle implicit gay hatred, he immediately closes multiple players' support tickets without any explanation or answers. 

So if you're a gay dude looking for fun in a kinky virtual world, don't waste your time and go find a better game. We're clearly not welcome here.

这款游戏不仅布满了可能让你的游戏电脑变成爆炸微波炉的千百个漏洞，更充斥着无能且充满深层恐同倾向的开发者和工作人员。

他们从未为同性恋玩家群体更新动画效果，却几乎每周为其他群体（仅限女同性恋者和异性恋者）进行更新。

更糟的是，游戏所有者/管理员（Mi**y）极其不专业且态度粗鲁。每当有人质疑游戏缺乏同性恋动画更新及隐含的反同倾向时，他便立即关闭多名玩家的支持工单，拒绝任何解释或答复。

所以如果你是想在变态虚拟世界寻欢作乐的同志，别浪费时间了，赶紧去找更好的游戏吧。我们显然在这里不受欢迎。

first of all, my expectations were already bottomed out below the floor for this game. most games like this are built solely on the idea of gooning and thats it.

imagine my surprise when i get on for the first time and i see a bunch of people i've never met before hanging out in "clans" together and partying hard and being social

now im sure you are asking yourself, "then why the negative review?"

well i'll tell you why: its not the players, or the community driven events, or the gooning

the Devs of this MMO are some of the most erratically out of touch people i've ever had the displeasure of dealing with

first of all, the game master server is located somewhere in Russia, that much is evident by the sheer number of untranslated UI elements. they haven't been fixed yet numerous players have complained about it

wanna know what else hasn't been fixed

-the stupidly long loading times
-the random server time-outs
-the server being unoptimized to the point where playing with graphics settings set to anything higher than the lowest settings make it run at (and i shit you not) 5 fps MAX
-spawning into event spaces still placing your character underneath the world

the list goes on, and yet the devs still push out new paid animations and items to goon with
really makes me wonder if the devs actually give a care about the game or the communities within it or if its solely to make a quick buck from down bad gooner elites who cant live without gooning 24/7

time tells all i guess

First launch: I can see the vision... but the game ran in fits and starts, areas with lots of avatars ran horrifically slowly while areas without avatars ran decently well.    

Second launch: Spent 10 minutes waiting for this game to load - after consuming 40+% of my 8 core/16 thread 10th Gen CPU, nearly 9 GB of RAM and 70+% of my RTX 2060... it never completed loading but turned my system into a wind tunnel.  Poor.

Overall impression: Not ready for prime time.

⭐☆☆☆☆

Playtime: 60 minutes

30 minutes: Trying to fix the lag

10 minutes: Realizing there’s no fixing the lag

20 minutes: Watching a guy ride a horse with a fire extinguisher inside an apartment while people were having bathtub org!es and strangers spammed emojis

PC Specs (a.k.a. Sacrificial Offering to LoveCraft):

Ryzen 5600x

RTX 3070

32 GB RAM (12 GB held hostage by this game)

2TB NVMe SSD

FPS achieved: 15 (on a good day)

So here’s the deal: LoveCraft is free. But nothing in this “game” actually feels free, except regret.

Let’s talk performance.
My rig can run Cyberpunk 2077 at max settings like it’s butter on a hot pan. LoveCraft? Barely crawls above 15 FPS, even on low settings, while rendering what looks like 2005-era Second Life knockoff graphics. My character was basically a Picasso painting in 3D. I opened Task Manager and the game was chewing 12GB of RAM just idling in the menu. For reference, Elden Ring doesn’t even do that.

Now let’s talk monetization.
This is where the comedy gold really begins. Behold:

Premium Plan ($45):

5% discount in the store (wow, thanks for the generosity 🙄)

Create three avatars (because two would be too mainstream)

“High-end real estate” (translation: a digital shoebox apartment)

Colored nickname and a little icon so everyone knows you paid real money for fake clout.

VIP Plan ($350):

All sex animations are FREE. Yes, apparently animations cost money otherwise.

20% store discount (still overpriced as hell)

Transfer golden coins, extra avatars, blah blah…

The true prize: a yellow name and a little “VIP” badge so everyone knows you spent $350 to roleplay as a h0rny landlord in low-res graphics.

I’m sorry, but who in their right mind spends three hundred and fifty dollars for this? For that price, you could buy a Steam Deck and play literally anything else.

And don’t get me started on the in-game shop:

Clothes: a pair of underwear costs more gold than an actual Calvin Klein set. Not exaggerating.

Pets: there is a giant soft c0ck with eyes and a mouth you can buy for $20. That’s not even funny, it’s just terrifying.

Mounts: You can buy mountains to ride. Yes. You pay to sit on geological formations.

The only “realistic” part of this game is that housing is stupid expensive. You want a house? That’s $50 USD. And it looks like a box from The Sims 1.

My actual experience in-game:
I log in, the game immediately stutters like a dying fish. After trying to fix lag for half an hour, I gave up. Then I wandered into an apartment where a dude was riding a horse with a fire extinguisher, while another group was roleplaying a bathtub 0rgy with a live emoji audience. At that moment, I realized: this isn’t a game. This is performance art made entirely out of bad decisions.

Comparison time:

VRChat: 7,538.4 hours (yes, mostly ERP, but at least it’s fun and customizable). I can build worlds, upload avatars, dance with friends, and ERP in anime catgirl form, all for free.

LoveCraft: 60 minutes, and I feel like I need therapy.

Even S3x with H!tler is more honest than this trash. At least that game doesn’t pretend to be anything more than what it is.

Final Verdict:
LoveCraft is “free,” but the real price is your dignity.

💀 0/10. Would rather spend $350 on actual Calvin Klein underwear than fake pixels.

Well, despite spending a lot of time here, the game disappoints me. The game mechanics are archaic, the game can freeze during "encounters", and returning is often difficult due to lenghty data loading times. Many nice initial relationships fall apart before they even begin. It's a nightmare....but if someone, usually a lot of kids - most of who are here - want quick, shotr, and meaningless encounters, then this game is for them. Not for friendship, you won't find it here. It's for, i guess, the foolish satisfaction of emotionally immature children.

But really hasn't, only fun thing is all the outfits. But just...not worth it over all.
